Laptop Vs Notebook

While both of these computers are designed to be portable, there are differences in them that can be used to determine which one is the best option for your needs.  The following comparisons will show you the differences between the two.

DVD Drives

A laptop has an integrated DVD driveA notebook does not have an integrated DVD drive, but usually has a connection to allow one to be connected externally

Manufacturers

Laptops are generally manufactured by Dell, HP, ASUS, Lenovo, Compaq, Samsung, Toshiba, and Alienware.Notebooks are usually made by Samsung, Apple, Toshiba, Dell, and Sony.

RAM (Random Access Memory)

When it comes to memory, laptops generally have something between 1GB to 8GB of RAM.Notebooks generally have much smaller memory than laptops. However, many newer models do contain bigger memory depending on the manufacturer.

Cooling Abilities

A laptop has built in fans that are powerful, and are designed to adjust their cooling capacity based on the current state of usage.Notebooks are not equipped with extensive cooling capabilities due to having significantly less processor power than laptops.

Screen Size

Laptops have screens that are anywhere from 12 inches up to 19 inches in the viewing area.Notebook screens can range in size from 9 inches up to around 15 inches in the viewing area, although some manufacturers offer larger screens on some versions.

Weight

A laptop computer generally weighs between 3 and 12 pounds, so they can be rather cumbersome to carry around in a carrying case for an extended amount of time.Notebooks are much lighter than laptops, and usually weigh around 5 pounds or less.

Uses

Laptops are designed to replicate the abilities and power of a desktop computer, yet are small enough to be used on a lap or small table.Notebook computers are designed to have some of the features and functionality of a desktop, but are usually not able to handle as many programs or open windows due to their smaller processor
